quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Over his 14-year career at Google. Ken Norton led product teams at built Google Docs, Google Calendar, Google Maps, and even did a stint at Google Ventures.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Establishes Ken’s hands-on leadership experience across multiple iconic products, grounding the credibility of the lessons to follow.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The products that he's helped craft are now used by over three billion people.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete scale data point that signals the magnitude of impact behind Ken’s product leadership experience.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we cover the creative versus reactive mindset, why the art of product management is much more important than the science of product management, how to get over imposter syndrome, the most common PM blind spots, how to find a coach and how to know if a coach is right for you, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Previews several practical mental models and coaching-oriented topics (mindset, craft vs. science, blind spots) that practitioners can apply.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Give your teams self-service product data to understand your users, drive conversions, and increase engagement, growth, and revenue.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Actionable advice on enabling teams with self-serve analytics to directly impact key business outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Amplitude is the number one most popular analytics solution in the world, used by both big companies like Shopify, Instacart, and Atlassian, and also most tech startups.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption claim plus recognizable examples to benchmark tooling choices.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And I personally review and accept just 10% of them to be part of this collective.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A specific selection-rate data point that signals a curated, high-signal hiring pool.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You'll only hear from companies that you want to hear from.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A practitioner-friendly principle for controlling inbound opportunities and reducing noise in job search.

quotes.topic_title: Donut metaphor and remote equivalent
quotes.text: I'm not even sure if the physical equivalent of donuts is donuts.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Reframes the famous donut idea as a deeper principle rather than a literal tactic, prompting practitioners to focus on intent over form.

quotes.topic_title: Donut metaphor and remote equivalent
quotes.text: I mean when I came up with that, I think it was really to be a metaphor around being a servant leader, bringing whatever needs to be done, filling the white space, filling the gaps, whatever needed to happen.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Defines the underlying leadership model (servant leadership) and a practical heuristic: proactively fill gaps and do what’s needed.

quotes.topic_title: Donut metaphor and remote equivalent
quotes.text: There was a PM who got DoorDash codes and found the best local donut place for each of the people on the team and basically sent them a code and said, "Click here and order the donuts to come to your house whenever you want them."
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, remote-friendly example of translating an in-person team-building gesture into a distributed setting.

quotes.topic_title: Donut metaphor and remote equivalent
quotes.text: So maybe at least partially the digital equivalent of donuts might be actual donuts.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Offers a simple, actionable takeaway: remote equivalents can still be the same gesture, just delivered differently.

quotes.topic_title: What executive coaching is and why Ken coaches
quotes.text: To me, I see executive coaching as a partnership or creative partnership. It's all about helping my client reach their goals, their potential, whatever that means to them. So an important thing about coaching is the definition of success does belong to the client. I don't have an agenda.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Defines a client-led coaching framework where success criteria are owned by the client, not the coach.

quotes.topic_title: What executive coaching is and why Ken coaches
quotes.text: My coaching practice, I coach the whole person. So there is no restriction on what we might talk on, what we might work on together. It's not limited to product. It's not even limited to work or even leadership. It's wherever they want to go, whatever change, transformation means to them.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Expands the scope of coaching beyond job performance to unlock deeper, more durable change.

quotes.topic_title: What executive coaching is and why Ken coaches
quotes.text: As coaches, we bring a bunch of tools to the conversation. The most important ones, honestly, are probably listening and curiosity, intuition, open-mindedness, really there to help challenge them to see things in different ways, help them tap into their imagination, figure out when there might be underlying beliefs, help them connect dots that need to be connected, help them disconnect things that feel connected.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Gives a practical “toolkit” of coaching behaviors practitioners can apply immediately in 1:1s.

quotes.topic_title: What executive coaching is and why Ken coaches
quotes.text: You start to realize advice is not as powerful as you might think it is. It's a little bit like cotton candy. Doesn't have a lot of nutrition. You get a nice sugar high. You feel great, both sides feel happy, but then a couple weeks later, a couple months later, nothing's really changed.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that advice often creates short-term satisfaction without lasting behavior change.

quotes.topic_title: What executive coaching is and why Ken coaches
quotes.text: I mean so it was these just twin pillars of wanting to figure out where I could do what I like the most, and then also recognizing that where growth comes from is less around advice and telling people what to do and more about helping them figure out their own path, their own way.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Summarizes a growth model: shift from telling to enabling self-discovery to drive real development.

quotes.topic_title: Who seeks coaching and when
quotes.text: Often they come to me because there's a career milestone or a crossroads, and it could be that they now find themselves in the position of being a CPO for the first time.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Highlights a common trigger point—new leadership scope—when coaching becomes most valuable.

quotes.topic_title: Who seeks coaching and when
quotes.text: Maybe there's a new industry change, or they've gone from a big company to a startup and a have this sense of what got me here isn't going to get me there.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for recognizing when past strengths won’t scale to a new context or role.

quotes.topic_title: Who seeks coaching and when
quotes.text: I think my clients are also very introspective and surrounded by great mentors and advisors and have all sorts of people in their life who can help them, but are realizing that a lot of the work is going to be internal work that's going to get them to the next level.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Reframes “leveling up” as primarily internal development even when external support is abundant.

quotes.topic_title: Who seeks coaching and when
quotes.text: And so, this transformation is going to be just as much what I need to do as who I am.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A concise, quotable framing of leadership growth as behavior change plus identity work.

quotes.topic_title: Internal operating system vs skills (driving analogy)
quotes.text: Now suddenly you're behind the wheel of the car. This is what my son is doing. Wow. Is it different than you thought it was going to be? Is it way more complicated? You have to remember check your mirrors. You've got to look before you turn. You didn't even know what that sign meant. You didn't know what those stripes meant. It is just overloading with complication and your internal mindset for confronting this challenge is not going to suit you the way you used to approach the world.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A vivid story showing how stepping into a new role reveals hidden complexity and demands a different mindset, not just more effort.

quotes.topic_title: Internal operating system vs skills (driving analogy)
quotes.text: And so, there is this sense that what is interesting about driving is the world hasn't gotten any more complex. Driving's always been driving. But now your place in the world has shifted such that the internal meaning-making and self-complexity that is required requires a complete reboot of the internal operating system in order to allow you to thrive there.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A memorable framework: leadership growth often requires upgrading your “internal operating system” as your role changes, even if the external world hasn’t.

quotes.topic_title: Internal operating system vs skills (driving analogy)
quotes.text: And so, when you talk about this question of how much of this is skills, how much of this is tactics, how much of this is learning versus how much is internal growth, the answer is it's both, but the shift that is required is very much around how your inner self can make meaning and respond to the demands of the world around you so that you can succeed and thrive in this mindset shift that happens.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Practical guidance for coaching and self-development: address both skill-building and the deeper meaning-making shift required to operate at the next level.

quotes.topic_title: Internal operating system vs skills (driving analogy)
quotes.text: The skills matter, but by this point, you're beyond the place where you've learned the skills. There's mastering the skills, but there is this sense of what developmental psychologists call self-complexity, the ability to respond and adapt to that.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A counterintuitive point: after a certain level, progress is less about learning new skills and more about increasing adaptive capacity (“self-complexity”).

quotes.topic_title: Internal operating system vs skills (driving analogy)
quotes.text: I mean every day something changes. It forces us to respond and adapt. So there aren't even rules of the road in product.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A punchy observation that reframes product leadership as continuous adaptation in a domain without stable “rules.”

quotes.topic_title: Leadership unlock: creative versus reactive mindset
quotes.text: The most frightening part about it is you look around and everyone is looking at you like you're the designer of the game, and you thought you were playing.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A memorable metaphor for the leadership transition where success requires shifting from executing within rules to shaping the rules.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership unlock: creative versus reactive mindset
quotes.text: Here's the distinction. Very simple. Are you responding to the world from a place of fear, where you see problems and threats, you want to be right, you want to be liked, you're defensive as an inward approach, or are you responding to the world from a place of openness, possibility, curiosity, passion, growth, purpose?
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A clear diagnostic framework for identifying whether you’re leading reactively (fear-based) or creatively (possibility-based).

quotes.topic_title: Leadership unlock: creative versus reactive mindset
quotes.text: Bob Anderson, Bill Adams are two management scientists who've written extensively, done a whole bunch of research, and they have looked at every possible dimension you can imagine of success, both leadership capability, they've looked at revenue, brand, profitability, everything, and it's shown, yes, this creative form of leadership is in every possible way positively correlated with success and reactive leadership is negatively correlated.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Grounds the creative-vs-reactive model in research and ties it directly to measurable business outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership unlock: creative versus reactive mindset
quotes.text: Yet, according to their research, some 75% of leaders are primarily operating reactively.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A striking data point that challenges assumptions about how most leaders actually operate day-to-day.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership unlock: creative versus reactive mindset
quotes.text: It's not an easy thing that you flip the switch of. It goes back to this notion of redesigning that internal operating system, so how you confront the world, what underlying belief systems and assumptions you have that are causing you to operate from that place.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Actionable reframing: sustainable leadership change requires working on underlying beliefs, not just surface behaviors.

quotes.topic_title: Reactive postures: approval, rightness, control
quotes.text: Fear and anxiety is the way. That's how you know. You're just like, "Ugh, I'm below the line." I'm just like I'm seeing problems. I'm seeing threats.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A practical self-diagnostic for recognizing when you’ve slipped into reactive leadership mode.

quotes.topic_title: Reactive postures: approval, rightness, control
quotes.text: I like the word postures because it seems to click different ways that we retreat into this reactive mode.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model (“postures”) for categorizing reactive behaviors.

quotes.topic_title: Reactive postures: approval, rightness, control
quotes.text: Here, this is why this is so vexing is it actually worked really well. It was pretty effective.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Counterintuitive point: reactive strategies can be adaptive early, which is why they’re hard to outgrow.

quotes.topic_title: Reactive postures: approval, rightness, control
quotes.text: But there came a point where I gave away so much power that it was hurting me when it came to purpose and execution and decisiveness.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Highlights the specific career cost of approval-seeking: reduced ability to drive outcomes as scope grows.

quotes.topic_title: Reactive postures: approval, rightness, control
quotes.text: For me, the key to that was letting go of needing to be liked and redefining it as an admiration that takes place over time. So rather than I want to leave this room with everyone liking me, I started to realize I want to be the type of leader where, a decade later, people say, "I would work with that guy again in a heartbeat."
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A concrete reframe practitioners can apply: optimize for long-term respect and rehire-ability over short-term likability.

quotes.topic_title: Shifting from people-pleasing to purpose-led leadership
quotes.text: I think there's an appreciation that you have to understand what is holding you back. This is a lot of the work that I'll do with my clients is what is those underlying expectations? What are these underlying beliefs?
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Actionable coaching lens: progress starts by identifying the hidden expectations and beliefs driving people-pleasing behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Shifting from people-pleasing to purpose-led leadership
quotes.text: It's like, okay, what is the underlying belief I'm making about what leadership is there? There's an archetype that I have in my mind that is incompatible with this this way.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A practical reframing tool: diagnose the “leader archetype” you’re comparing yourself to and challenge whether it’s actually required.

quotes.topic_title: Shifting from people-pleasing to purpose-led leadership
quotes.text: Maybe I don't believe it's possible to be another type of leader.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Counterintuitive blocker: the constraint is often imagination/belief (what leadership can look like), not capability.

quotes.topic_title: Shifting from people-pleasing to purpose-led leadership
quotes.text: There's 360-degree assessments that are very helpful here that will start to help you understand, hey, here are places where you're operating actively. Here are places where you're operating really creatively, because, by the way, most people are partially somewhere in that journey. It's a developmental process.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Concrete methodology: use 360 feedback to locate where you’re in reactive vs. creative modes and treat leadership as a developmental arc.

quotes.topic_title: Shifting from people-pleasing to purpose-led leadership
quotes.text: The number of times when I'm with a client in coaching and say, "Well, what if you did do that?" and they go, "It just won't work." You realize that there is this wiring in there that needs ... And this is what I talk about, this operating system that needs to be rejiggered to start to make sense of what if it did and how might you know.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Memorable mental model: resistance often comes from “OS-level” wiring that must be rewired via experiments and evidence, not willpower.

quotes.topic_title: Authentic leadership and career navigation
quotes.text: The main thing that she helped me see is you can do all the things that you want to do through the lens of the strengths that you have and not have to force yourself to be good at these other things, because there's many ways to accomplish the same outcomes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical strengths-based reframing: pursue the same outcomes by leaning into your strengths instead of trying to fit a single leadership archetype.

quotes.topic_title: Authentic leadership and career navigation
quotes.text: It was a very meandering, reactive path. It was like every so often I was catching a wave, and I knew what it felt like to be on the wave, but I didn't know what the characteristics of the wave were.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A memorable metaphor for diagnosing career fit: identify the conditions that make you thrive rather than relying on luck and reacting to circumstances.

quotes.topic_title: Authentic leadership and career navigation
quotes.text: Then you start to say, okay, well, what if rather than just randomly meandering through my career, I actually elevated needing to connect, wanting to be helpful? Then you're like what would it be like if I wanted the helping professions? It's just a reframing of move through your career in a way that seems externally to fit some definition of success and to start to define that internally.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for career navigation: elevate your intrinsic drivers and use them to choose roles, instead of optimizing for external definitions of success.

quotes.topic_title: Authentic leadership and career navigation
quotes.text: That is the very definition of the reactive versus creative mindset. Reactive, allowing the world to set the expectations and try to meet them versus tap into what your real, true sense of purpose and vision is. Then use that to navigate the world.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A clear mental model (reactive vs. creative) for shifting from external validation to internally-driven decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Authentic leadership and career navigation
quotes.text: Absolutely. That's why I think so much of the focus on the skills, the frameworks, it can be limited as you develop these capabilities, because it's inner work.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A counterintuitive leadership point: skill-building and frameworks can plateau unless paired with deeper self-understanding and belief work.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching vs mentoring and when coaching fits
quotes.text: You start to pick up on that shift when it's less of the goals being defined externally and more of the goals being defined internally.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic for when someone is moving from externally-driven ambition to internally-driven motivation—often the inflection point where coaching becomes valuable.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching vs mentoring and when coaching fits
quotes.text: Then you start to notice the shift and it starts to become more of, "Well, because really what's important to me is creativity. I want more creativity in my life. I want more ability to challenge other people."
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A concrete example of reframing a surface goal (title/promotion) into underlying values that can guide better career and leadership decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching vs mentoring and when coaching fits
quotes.text: If we go back to that video game analogy, if you're looking for someone to just teach you the tutorial so you can learn how to play the video game and there's this jackass like me sitting next to you and saying, "What's important to you about playing this video game?" you're going to be like, "Just can you tell me how to hold the controller? Can you stop?"
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A memorable way to decide between coaching vs. instruction: coaching is the wrong tool when someone needs basics and concrete how-to guidance.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching vs mentoring and when coaching fits
quotes.text: So it's not always right. It's a place where I think oftentimes people recognize that they've gotten all the advice, all the frameworks, all the rules, all the tricks, all the tips. They've learned that, they've mastered it, they've tweaked it, they've optimized it, they've recognized the shortcomings, they've customized it. The emergence that's required for them to get to the next level is just going to come just as much from inside them as it is from outside, if not more.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A clear criterion for when coaching fits: after you've exhausted external playbooks, the next level requires internal transformation rather than more tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching vs mentoring and when coaching fits
quotes.text: So skills run the gamut, but it's a question of how much are you looking for someone to tell you the right way versus how much do you believe that there even is no right way? It's ultimately going to have to be your way.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A decision-making lens for choosing mentorship vs. coaching based on whether you need “the right way” or need to discover “your way.”

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: According to AngelList head of product, "Banking makes every single feature more interesting. With it, our platform functions as financial mission control for our customers. Without it, we're just another software tool in a big messy stack."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable positioning model: embedding banking can transform a product from a commodity tool into a central system of record/control for customers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Embedding banking into your product not only adds differentiation, but also helps you acquire, retain, and monetize your customers.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical growth lens for evaluating embedded finance: it can impact the full funnel (acquisition, retention, monetization), not just differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Unit is the market leader in banking as a service, combining multiple bank partners with a developer-friendly API to empower companies of all sizes to launch accounts, cards, payments, and lending in just a few weeks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete methodology/approach: use a BaaS platform to ship a full suite of financial products quickly rather than building everything from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: Finding coaching without a coach: self-work and resources
quotes.text: Here's the secret about the coaching industry. Anyone can call themselves a coach. It's very democratized. It's great. There's no gatekeepers and barriers and there's no 500 licenses you have to go through.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Reframes coaching as more accessible than people assume, lowering the perceived barrier to getting help.

quotes.topic_title: Finding coaching without a coach: self-work and resources
quotes.text: The other thing is that you don't need a coach who's done the job before.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Challenges the common belief that effective coaching requires domain expertise, expanding who you can seek out.

quotes.topic_title: Finding coaching without a coach: self-work and resources
quotes.text: I love doing values work, like, "What are your values? Okay. No. What really are your values?" That's something you can do yourself. That's something you can question. You can read about, you can start to understand.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Gives a concrete self-coaching practice (iterative values clarification) that practitioners can apply immediately.

quotes.topic_title: Finding coaching without a coach: self-work and resources
quotes.text: Great managers, I think, especially the best product leaders, understand how to put the coach hat on and when it's appropriate to put the coach hat on, and are explicit about that, are like, "Okay, let me take off my manager hat now and put the coach hat on. What do you really want to do, Lenny? What's important to you? What's your career?" And so, I think you can get coaching from everywhere.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Introduces a practical “manager hat vs. coach hat” model for getting (and offering) coaching in everyday work relationships.

quotes.topic_title: Finding coaching without a coach: self-work and resources
quotes.text: There's a lot of self-coaching you can do. This is honestly one of the benefits for me having gone through tons of training and coaching is starting to coach myself, like feeling an emotion and asking myself coach questions. Really powerful.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Describes a repeatable self-coaching method—notice emotion, then ask coach-style questions—to build independence without a formal coach.

quotes.topic_title: Common PM blind spot: people over product
quotes.text: I think probably the number one category, I'm not sure it's necessarily a problem, but maybe category or problems, is ... And this is, I think, great lesson for people earlier in their career, is how much all of the challenges that senior executives are dealing with come down to people versus product.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Reframes senior product leadership as primarily a people/influence challenge rather than a product/strategy challenge.

quotes.topic_title: Common PM blind spot: people over product
quotes.text: Part of what I think is pretty exciting about product management is you are a leader from day one in product management. There's leadership all over the place, but that's your job. You're a leader. You don't have any formal authority, but you're a leader. You're expected to lead.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A clear mental model for PM work: leadership without authority is the core job, not a later-career add-on.

quotes.topic_title: Common PM blind spot: people over product
quotes.text: The art is communication, collaboration, the more fuzzy, softer skills, people stuff. It's an elevation of that being just as important, if not more important, over time, as all this skills, techniques, tactics, managing a backlog, all that kind of stuff that you have to do. You should invest in that the same way you invest in those other skills.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Provides an “art vs. science” framework and a concrete directive to invest in soft skills like any other PM competency.

quotes.topic_title: Common PM blind spot: people over product
quotes.text: So if you go off to a training to learn a technique for doing, I don't know, some sort of technical dashboard analysis, why don't you go to training to learn how to have difficult conversations?
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: Actionable advice to treat difficult-conversation training as equally legitimate and necessary as technical skill training.

quotes.topic_title: Common PM blind spot: people over product
quotes.text: What I would recommend is just appreciating that these are going to really, really matter and practicing and then valuing them and not thinking of them as something that either will matter later or a distraction or not really part of the job.
quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.context: A practical mindset shift: prioritize and practice people skills now rather than deferring them as “nice-to-haves.”

quotes.topic_title: Transition to imposter syndrome discussion (cut off)
quotes.text: Speaking of difficult and squishy, I'm guessing that one of the biggest challenges that people you work with face and one of the most recurring themes is imposter syndrome, people having imposter syndrome, something definitely I went through and it comes up a lot on this podcast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights imposter syndrome as a common, recurring challenge among practitioners and leaders, normalizing it as widespread rather than isolated.

quotes.topic_title: Transition to imposter syndrome discussion (cut off)
quotes.text: What do you usually advise your clients to do when they're feeling imposter syndrome?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Directly tees up the practical, actionable coaching question that many listeners face and want concrete guidance on.
